document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: Mr. and Mrs. R. C. Moore, Jr. of Fairfax are spending a j few days with Mrs. T. N. Saul, i Mr. and Mrs. T. C. Beasley of Roanoke spent the week end I in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Kemper Beasley, Sr. Recent visitors in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond G. Barr were Mrs. Rutha Barr, Mrs. Grover Barr, Mrs. Etta Riddle, Mr. and Mrs. Joe Barr all of Farmville, Mr. and Mrs. Ray L. Duty, Karla Lea of An- dersonville. Sunday visitors of Mr. and Mrs. A.N. M orris were Mrs. Curtis Nester and daughter of Lynchburg. Mr. and Mrs. W. A. Haver and family of Dillwyn were Sun day visitors of Mr. and Mrs. Roger M orris. Mr. and Mrs. Bennie Wil liams and M rs. Ruth Beasley spent the week end with Mr. and Mrs. Sam Baldwin at Rust- burg. Mr. and Mrs. Kelly Branch and family of Buckingham visit ed Mr. and M rs. Kemper Beas ley, Sr. Saturday night. The community was saddened last week by the death of the Rev. Keith Whitehead at New Market, Tenn. Mr. and Mrs. Bob Bryan, Phillip and David attended the funeral there F ri day. Sunday visitors of Mr. and Mrs. Rice Seay at Anderson- ville were Mr. and Mrs. Roger Morris and family. The Youth Group of the Chest nut Grove Baptist Church at tended a Billy Graham Movie at Lynchburg Saturday night. Mrs. Lucy Glover has re  turned to her home after visit ing Mr. and Mrs. Kermit Cook in Richmond. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Glover of Lynchburg vi sited his mother Sunday. Mr. and Mrs. Kemper Beas ley, Sr. visited in the Wyatt Elliott home at Curdsville Sun day. The regular W.M.S. Meeting will be held in the home of Mrs. Carrie Senger Friday, Nov. 15,

document.text: General Wyatt M. Elliott, clerk of the United States Circuit and District courts died in Lynchburg at his home after a brief illness j Thursday 25th, ult. General Elliott was born in Campbell conntv, Febru ary 25,1823. A t an early age, being only 8 years old he removed to Buckingham county where he re ceived his earliest education, at the age of 16 he was sent to the Virginia Military Institute after which course he taught school, then taking up t course of law, he then became asso dated in the publication of tin Richmond W hig until the first year of the late war, in which he figured as a man, soldier, lieutenant, colonel and general, his deeds of daring aud adventure were many aud thrilling. document.text: T will sing at mercy and jud-  gement unto thee, O Lord, will I sing. Psalms 1011 The appreciate service for the Pastor Rev. C. L. Elliott and wife were a successful one. Called Elliotts night. The M.C. was Rev. H. O. Flood. Open song by the choir,  Pass Me Not. Prayer by Deacon Wyatt Vernable and scripture reading by William Haskins, taken from Psalm 1011-5. Song by church choir We are March ing  lead by Leon Wesley. Welcome address Mrs. Alice Moore, response by one Rev. Elliott family from Pilot Mt. Baptist Church. Church paper read by Mrs. Catherine Has kins. Three letters meaning so much We Thank You. Guest minister was Rev. James Mil ler sermon  Hold On. Every one enjoyed the wonderful mes sage. Special song by choir Hold On Just A Little While Longer. Offering lifted by Dea. L. M. Harvey, Dea. Woodrow Haskins, and Dea. Eddie Han cock. A lovely offering was lifted. A corsage of white carn ations were pinned on Mrs. Ida Elliott by Mrs. Minerva Vena ble also a cake was given with 12 candles representing 12 years of service, baked by Mrs. Bertha King. A crown was placed upon Rev. Elliotts head consisting of 120.50 . Mrs. Catherine Haskins, members of the church and friends gave donations for the crown. A special solo was sung by mem bers of Elliott family  Give Me My Flowers . Remarks by Mrs. Catheine Haskings Mrs. Lessie Thompson, Mrs. Elliott. A book was given to Rev. Elliott by Dea. Wyatt Venable. Remarks by pastor Elliott. A song was lead  Somewhere Around God Throne. Closing remarks Rev. James Miller at the close of the sermon photos were taken by Rev. Elliotts son, Mr. Ray mond Elliott and William Has kins. Mrs. Haskins wishes to thank everyone for their pre sent and their kind ways and actions to make this program a success. Thank you again.

Rev. 141 The regular Drenching serv- i ice will be held at the Alabama - Baptist Church, Pastor, Rev. Curtis Elliott, pulpit guest, Rev. Wyatt T. Venable, Pastor New Store Baptist Church in Buckingham. Prayer service will be lead by Miss Pearl Moore and Miss Ruth Jackson. The scriptures and prayer in morning service read by Rev. Venable. A large crowd attended morning serv ice. It was enjoyed by all. A love offering was lifted for Mrs. Ida Daniel. We thank each visiting person who attended our services, visiting deacons from Mt. Lyle, St. Louis, White Oak Grove and Mt. Pleasant. The third Anniversary of Gospel Quintet of Pamplin, Va. was a great success an over flow crowd gathered to hold the celebration. M. C. Freddie Munford of Richmond, Devo tion lead by Young Adult Junior Choir of White Rock Baptist Church, Lynchburg, Va. Opening song - Leaning on His Everlasting Arm, Scripture Miss Ruth Jackson, Prayer by Deacon Arther Watkins, song by choir, Christ Is All, Welcome given by Mrs. Linda Watkins and response by Mrs. Mattie Lawson. document.text: A very large crowd of ministers, deacons and friends attended the ordination of two young men to the Deacon Board of the Zion Baptist Church last Sunday evening at 330. The pastor of the church. Rev. L. E. Hankins, led the devotionals and extended a cordial welcome to all who came. After the welcome the clerk, Mrs. 0. W. Smith, called the list of ministers and churches invited. After direc tions from the pastor the following council was formed as follows Moderator, Rev. R. Q. Lawing Clerk, Deacon Frank Johnson Ordination sermon, Rev. C. L. Elliott Charge to the Church, Rev. Wyatt Venable Charge to the candidates, Rev. Jordan Presentation of the Bible, Rev. Carmore Presenta tion of the hymn book Rev. Richardson Ordination prayer, Rev. Roy Wood Right Hand of Fellowship, Deacon Otis Scott Offering, the Candidates, Dea cons Lawson and Toney Ferguson. The service was very impressive and every one was spiritually feed. A large crowd attended the regular preaching service at the Zion Baptist Church Sunday morning at 11 a.m. The pastor Rev. L. E. Hankins delivered an inspiring sermon on the subject On the Other Side of the Road. There were visitors from the Morning Star Baptist Church present. Beauti ful music was rendered by the Senior Choir under the direction of Mrs. Grace Wormack. All present were uplifted. The offering was great. Impressive services were held at the Galilee Baptist Church Sunday morning at 11 a.m. with the pastor Rev. Lawing in charge. Special music was rendered by the Junior and Senior Choirs. The right hand of fellowship was given to five new members. After the fellowship the holy

document.text: Blessed in the man that walketh not in the counsel of the ungodlynor standeth in the way of sinners, nor sitteth in the seat of the scornful. Psalms 1L Prayer Service at 1130. Mrs. Alidfe Moore and Mrs. Cather ine Haskins were in charge. Everyone joined in the service. Happy New Year to every one is extended from the pastor and members of the Alabama Church. Regular preaching service was held at the Alabama Baptist Church with our pastor Rev. Elliott in charge. Script ure reading was by Rev. Wyatt T. Venable. Prayer by Rev. Howard 0. Flood. Music was furnished by the Adult and Junior Choirs. Rev. Elliotts text was taken from Ezekiel 3626-27. Theme, GodjskNjOYear Gift. A splendid message was preach ed. Everyone seem to enjoy the sermon. A large crowd attend ed the service the first Sunday in the New Year.

document.text: The annual Freedom Fund Rally will come to a close this Sunday evening at 730 at the Galilee Baptist Church. The guest speaker will be Mr. Joseph F. Lewis, a former teacher in Appomattox and now a worker in the State Correctional System. The devo tional will be conducted by the pastor of the church with music furnished by the Galilee Senior Choir. All contestants are asked to report their monies to the finance committee between 7 and 720. Mrs. Annie Mae Humbles is chairman of the program committee. Each church in the county has been asked to cooperate. The rally is sponsored by the local branch of the NAACP. The general public is cordially invited to be present. The Mount Shiloh Baptist Church Usher Board will celebrate its anniversary on the first Sunday in November at 3 p.m. Local Usher Boards have been invited to take an active part. The Rev. Roger Ford has been invited to be the guest speaker. The talent program sponsor ed by Miss Evelyn Wright of the First Baptist Church last Sunday at 3 p.m. was enjoyed by all. The pastor of the church. Dr. K. W. Davis, conducted the devotions. He was assisted in the service by the Rev. R. Q. La wing. Music was furnished by the First Baptist Church gospel chorus under the direction of Mrs. H. P. James. Among the talents were the following A paper, Miss Evelyn Wright Duette, Mrs. Ora McCoy and son Reading, Mrs. Sally Reid Solo, Mr. Jam es Reid Solo, M aster Edward McCoy A dramaza- tion, Mary Had a Little Lamb by Mrs. Lillie Stevens Offering by Deacons Solomon and Edward McCoy Deacon Percy Johnson of Mount Airy gave the opening prayer. Mrs. Evelyn Berry rendered a solo. The offering was very good. Words of appreciaiton were given by the pastor and the benediction was given by Rev. La wing. The Rev. Wyatt Venable and his musical group will render a special service at the Promise Land Baptist Church on the second Sunday evening in November at 3 p.m. The officers, members and friends nyited to attend.. The Rev. Edward McCray f gpfappe of hwchoin will render service at the Galilee Baptist Church on the third Sunday evening in November at 730. Members and friends are asked to attend. A large crowd atten- od the regular preaching service at the Mount Shiloh Baptist Church last Sunday morning. The Rev. C. L. Elliott deliver! the morning message. Mrs. Eva C. Morgan, Mrs. Belle Terry and Mr. Thomas Patterson of Roanoke, were guests in the Howard Stevens home over the week end, also attending the Mount Airy Homecoming services in Appo-

Wyatt Venable The Morning Sun Baptist Church reported a success ful revival last week. The evangelist. was Rev. Philip Elliott of Lynchburg.

document.text: Prayer is the key to the kingdom. Faith unlocks the door. The regular preaching service was held at Gravel Hill Baptist Church this Sunday with the Rev. James Miller in charge. The message V was excellent, and enjoyed by .!!. The Adult Choir rendered beautiful music, accom panied by Mrs. Mattie Watson at piano. We were happy to welcome visitors from New Store, Peaks, Mt. Pleasant and Morriing Star Baptist Churches. The Spring revival was a great success. Participating ministers included The Rev. James Miller, Monday night, accompanied by his Adult Choir and pianist, Mattie Watson the Rev. Wyatt Venable, Tuesday, accompanied by the New Store Choir The Rev. Earl Jones, Wednesday, accompanied by the Jones Family The Rev. Earnest Humbles, Wednesday, accompanied by the Jordan Junior Choir, with Roberta Womack at piano the Rev. Curtis Elliott aided pastor Hum bles The Rev. Warren Napier, Friday, accompanied by the Mt. Pleasant Senior Choir, with Mr. James Moore at the piano. We wish to thank all who took part in the service. The Rev. William Venable and the Bobber Sisters will render the service at Gravel Hill Baptist Church the first Sunday in May at 3 p.m. Mrs. Elnora Woolridge is sponsor. The great evangelist, Mrs. Odell Johnson of Maryland will preach at Gravel Hill the third Sunday in May at 4 p.m. You are invited. Our prayers go out to the sick and shut-in.

document.text: Pat and Mike Torrence. Micah and Wyatt happily announce the arrival of thé newest member of their family, Brady Kipp. Born September 1- at Virginia Baptist Hospital, he weighed 9 lbs. 5 ozs. at birth. Maternal grandpa r e n t s are Jane and Jimmy Tibbs of Spout Springs. Paternal grandparents aré Lorraine and Elliott Torrence of Appomattox.

document.text: Our correspondent from Spanish Oaks writes Mr. James Shearer, one of our. most respected citizens lias been critically ill for move than a week and is hardly expected to recover, lie was found in an un conscious conditiou and has never fully regained consciousness since akeu. His trouble is thought to be heart disease. Later.Since the above was writ ten we learn that Mr. Shearer died yesterday. ..We are also very sorry to report the death of Kendrick Stratton, one of the oldest aud most highly re spected colored men of this com munity. Everybody knew Kendrick and he knew everybody in several counties around. lie was respected and trusted by all, and many will be truly sorry to hear of his death. He died from the effects of a neglected cold. Dr. Bice was called to see him when it was too late to do him any service. Dr. George B. Taylor is stirring up the Baptists before he takes his leave of absence. lie organized Monday night at Kirklea a C. C. C. class with the following enrolled as members Wyatt Abbitt, Mrs. Wyatt Abbitt, Miss Annie Abbitt, B. L. Burke, Miss Lacy Caldwell. Miss Dawson, Miss Mattie Jones, Prof. J. B. Loving, Geo. T. Peers. Miss Macca Sims, Geo. B. Taylor. Others will probably join the class. On the same day a Junior Bible Readers Class was started, with the following members Mattie, Lucy and Ethel Fleshman, Mary and Lula Irby Vara, Alice, Bet.tie and Eula May Burke, Helen Gregory, Mary Lizzie Paris, Becky Pnrdum, Walter Elliott, Elliott Tanner, Harry Han cock, Nathan Hancock, John Ab bitt and Evant Hunter. _______

document.text: On Sunday, August 17, the Torrence family as sembled at the Woodman of the World Building in Appomattox for the seven teenth consecutive family reunion. It was a most enjoyable day for. those who could attend. Attending and registering were Mrs. J. L Torrence, Elliott and, Lorraine Tor rence, Dennis, Pat and Zane, Larry, Gloria, Matt and Kim, Mike, Pat Ann, Micah and Wyatt, and Sheila and Mike Lewis. document.text: Mr. and Mrs. B. T. Blanks, of Richmond, arrived today to visit Mr. and Mrs. James Crawford.    Miss Dorothy Sears, of Peters burg, is spending the summer months with her mother, Mrs. J. E. Sears. 9 9 9 The Applewhite Circle of the W.M.U. of Liberty Baptist Church will meet with Mrs. G. L. Doss Monday, July 8 at 730 p.m.  9  Mrs. Clarence Franklin and children have returned from a weeks visit in Warrenton. Mrs. R. N. Ashworth and son, Tommy, are on a plane trip to California.  9 9 Miss Claudioe OBrien left Sat urday for New York from where she sailed Tuesday for a six week tour of Europe. She was accompanied to New York by Miss Kate E. .OBrien, of Farm ville, and Mr. and Mrs. Wyatt OBrien, of Chase City.    Miss Ginger Prieto, of St. Petersburg. Fla., is visiting her cousin. Miss Lina Trent.  9  9 Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Martin and Josie Ferguson and daughter, Joella, are on a motor trip through the New England States and Canada. 9 9 9 Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Elliott and two daughters, of Danville, and Mr. and Mrs. Sam Joe Paulette and daughter. Betty, of Halifax, visited Misses Ora and Phyllis Paulette for the week end. 9 9 -. Mr. and Mrs. Ben Wheeler and family are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Smith at Breaks, Va.    Mr. and Mrs. David M. Trent and two daughters, Brenda and Betty, are spending this week at Williamsburg, with Mr. and Mrs. John Tabb. 9 9 9 Mr. and Mrs. R. S. Dicky OBrien and son, Richard, Jr., of Key West, Fla., are spending several weeks in the hpme of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. H. OBrien.

document.text: Fund. Homecoming will be held at Alabama Church on the 5th Sunday in August. Morning service will be preached by Pastor Elliott. Revival will begin Monday night following service by pastor. Rev. Wyatt Venable will preach at Mt. Lyle Church on the 5th Sunday in August. Rev. Venable held his first revival last week at the Mt, Zion Baptist in Green Bay, Va Eleven souls were saved. Remember the sick where ever they might be.

document.text: Cheatham ---- Jen k in s The Crewe Baptist church was the scene of a very pretty wedding Saturday evening, September 10 th, when Miss Mary Esther Jenkins, daughter of Mr. Joseph Phillip Jenkins, became the bride of Mr. George Elliott Cheatham, of Spout Spring, Va. The ceremony was. perform ed by the Rev. W. H. Carter, pastor of the church, assisted by the Rev. J. W. Kincheloe, a former pastor. The church was beautifully decorated in cut flowers, ferns and cathedral candles. Mrs. L. G. Chappell rendered the wedding music, and Mrs R. E. Bacchus, of Norfolk, Va., a cousin of the bride, sang At Dawning. The bride entered with her father, who gave her away. Her wedding gown was made of white georgette, trimmed with silver lace, and the veil was caught with a spray of orange blossoms and she car ried a shower bouquet of brides roses and lillies of the valley. Miss Janet Wyatt, of Richmond, was,the brides maid of honor. She wore a pink taffeta dress trimmed with lace and carried rnssell roses. The matron of honor was Mrs. R. L. Ashburn, Jr., of Norfolk,I-r i , -n Va., another cousin, of the RuiiaboutjRGg. 3251 bride who wore a French dress

document.text: CANAAN BAPTIST On the first Sunday, Feb. 5, at 3 p.m. The Youth Club will sponsor a program. The guest speaker will be Rev. Wyatt Venerable and a ringing group of his choice. Mrs. Mary Randolph will be in charge. Regular preaching service, IFeb. 12. 1130 a.m. Rev. C. L. Elliott, pastor in charge. The Junior Choir will render the music. Please come and worship with us.

document.text: and Gospel Q uintet , of PampHn, Va. Thanksgiving night at 7 00 there will be a prayer service and Revi Wyatt Venable willpreach. Deacon William Venable preached his trial semton at White Oak Grove Baptist Sunday night. A large crowd turned out to the service and music was rendered by the Holiness Singers and Mr. Joyce Walker and Mrs., Mary Bailey. 1 Rev. Wyatt Venable was in charge of devotions. Rev. Waiter Singletary gave the prayer, scripture was given by Rev. Me, Johnson II Timothy 4-8 verse. Dedica tion prayer was offered by Rev. H. 0 Flood, special song. Rev. Curtis Elliott, Wont Have- To Cry No More, Rev. John Edwards was  present also. Rev. William Venable offered encouraging words. Rev. William Venable preached a splendid sermon. It was nronderful. Scripture was taken from Matthew 26 fel- 22  II Cor. 13-5 verse. Subject Look and Examine Yourself. Donations were good. Rev. Venable thanked each and everyone for coming out. MC. pastor Hendericks. See you next time! I-- i

document.text: Alabama Baptist Church yf m4 - And if I go and prepare a place for you.,1 will come again, and receive you unto myself, that where I am,, there ye may be also. Happy New Year To Everyone. The Alabama Baptist Church greets each and everyone in the name of Jesus, In the New Year 1976. We were happy to have Service the first Sunday in the New Year. With our pastor On duty, a large crowd attended our church service in the new. year. Our service began with prayer. Deacon James Moore, from Mt. Lyle Baptist Church read the scripture Prayer by Deacon Archer Watkins Spec ial song lead by Sister Alice Moore, Prayer Wheel Keep on Turning, song by Senior and Junior choir of church. Rev. E lliott opened the morning service with Rev. Wyatt Venable reading the scripture. Deacon Eddie Han cock with prayer, Special song lead by Mrs. Haskins, Some body Touch Me. Rev. Elliotts subject was If Jesus Go With, Me I Will Go., taken from 13 chap. St. John 14-16-33 verse 14 chap. St. John - 3 verse. Everyone really enjoyed the sermon. The offering was very good. Visiting deacons from following  churches Roanoke Baptist, Mt Lyle, White Oak Grove.. Special prayer went out to all the sick members and specicial prayer for Emmanuel Venable, Isaac Watkins and Deacon Levi Harvey. We thank each and everyone for coming out, to make a service a success. The Holiness Singers render ed a program at New Store Baptist Church at 4. And it was a great _ success. Rev. W yatt Venable, pastor, visiting minis ters were Rev. Curtis Elliott and JVfr-s. Elliott of Alabma Baptist Church
